page.title: 01General View Bradfield Moor
page.content: The land is mainly uncultivated, comprising both woodland and non woodland vegetation, heather and rocky areas. The main occupations are forestry and sheep farming. The woodland is mostly cultivated conifers, generally owned by the Fitzwillkiam family estates. To the south are the Dale Dyke and Strines reservoirs belonging to the Yorkshire Water Board. Thre are a few scattered farms, one public house (The Strines Inn) and an old manor (Hallfield House). This dairly remote area, part of the Peak District National Park, although having no bus service is frequented by hikers and weekend motorists. Private moorland to the north of the Strines is criss crossed with paths leading to Grouse moors and shooting butts.
